25BBD53F22FD49E6BC918E3F4CF7F7D7.description: identify, locate, and practice using keys on the keyboard, including letters, numbers, and special keys such as space bar and backspace.

40259AA31A5D42CB852880972457341F.description: practice ergonomically correct keyboarding techniques and developmentally appropriate hand and body positions; and

1614443E310740EA9FB16139DF506026.description: perform software application functions such as opening an application and modifying, printing, and saving digital artifacts using a variety of developmentally appropriate digital tools and resources;

53C05E8A3F4946118A7AD2239B9DDF4D.description: identify basic computer hardware, including a variety of input and output devices, and software using accurate terminology;

812944CF358244838B2451B8A7CEBDF1.description: use a variety of applications, devices, and online learning environments to engage with content;

15906B45B8094ADDBC48BB266301A428.description: Practical technology concepts--skills and tools. The student demonstrates knowledge and appropriate use of technology systems, concepts, and operations. The student is expected to:

A3174F6E81B140E9A0E4D7C141E66D1A.description: identify and discuss what information is safe to share online such as hobbies and likes and dislikes and what information is unsafe such as identifying information.

B3B46FC3963843D7B2D78A72FD64380C.description: identify ways to keep a user account safe, including not sharing login information and logging off accounts and devices; and

2D3E46C967F64F7C9B7A82268082DC46.description: Digital citizenship--privacy, safety, and security. The student practices safe, legal, and ethical digital behaviors to become a socially responsible digital citizen. The student is expected to:

A1490C5CC050499287964D66BFF776D1.description: communicate an understanding that all digital content has owners.

D6ADEA21903A4BCD83159BCAD31BEB87.description: demonstrate acceptable use of digital resources and devices as outlined in local policies or acceptable use policy (AUP); and

2BD64612D287474E9E317011D92E7B9B.description: Digital citizenship--ethics and laws. The student recognizes and practices responsible, legal, and ethical behavior while using digital tools and resources. The student is expected to:

A47280791B44491BACA2DBA553D2A795.description: Digital citizenship--social interactions. The student identifies appropriate ways to communicate in various digital environments. The student is expected to identify and demonstrate responsible behavior within a digital environment.

324A62D5211749A1ADAE4790DB254FB2.description: communicate with adult assistance the idea that digital devices can search for and retrieve information.

49DB1948F775419BBD69EFB498995E0B.description: communicate an understanding that data is information collected about people, events, or objects such as computer searches and weather patterns; and

322DF1DBF3FE4386B2814FCA77778825.description: Data literacy, management, and representation--collect data. The student defines data and explains how data can be found and collected. The student is expected to:

7DCD1A5BA3F14830984DDC2A887A54C5.description: use a design process with components such as asking questions, brainstorming, or storyboarding to identify and solve authentic problems with adult assistance.

C6785BE4D32347F0BDA72F33B03F614E.description: practice personal skills, including following directions, needed to successfully implement design processes; and

1F474B70C4FE4E559DEC84BEC437FC7E.description: Creativity and innovation--innovative design process. The student takes an active role in learning by using a design process to solve authentic problems for a local or global audience, using a variety of technologies. The student is expected to:

0830437464C54A63B5F276AD2B1E374E.description: Computational thinking--applications. The student, with guidance from an educator, applies the fundamentals of computer science. The student is expected to create a sequence of code with or without technology such as solving a maze using drag-and-drop programming or creating step-by-step directions for student movement to a specific location.

002B103C35364803818213479CF4551D.description: identify algorithms (step-by-step instructions) using a sequential process such as first, next, then, and last.

5C3B71982443494B87FCDBA9CF93680F.description: identify simple patterns and make predictions based on the patterns; and

4BBF9F0DFB794C8FB1FA88FAF9523820.description: identify a problem or task such as making a sandwich and break it down (decompose) into smaller pieces;

CB1ED948CE7C4A92A333FF778E426289.description: Computational thinking--foundations. The student explores the core concepts of computational thinking, a set of problem-solving processes that involve decomposition, pattern recognition, abstraction, and algorithms. The student is expected to:

64C91466DA7C4D9DBDB1064A13282F00.description: Statements containing the word "including" reference content that must be mastered, while those containing the phrase "such as" are intended as possible illustrative examples.

32172E5C5AC547D6A635DD820727EF0A.description: The technology applications TEKS can be integrated into all content areas and can support stand-alone courses. Districts have the flexibility of offering technology applications in a variety of settings, including through a stand-alone course or by integrating the technology applications standards in the essential knowledge and skills for one or more courses or subject areas.

12E44DB2288841449163D536FD945809.description: Practical technology concepts. Students build their knowledge of software applications and hardware focusing on keyboarding and use of applications and tools.

07B545B5289E4322A5D17681E821AB1B.description: Digital citizenship. Students practice the ethical and effective application of technology and develop an understanding of cybersecurity and the impact of a digital footprint to become safe, productive, and respectful digital citizens.

EE195DA00DE847ED80AD7D771A9E8589.description: Data literacy, management, and representation. Students collect, organize, manage, analyze, and publish various types of data for an audience.

0C59256A3B31494E991625C01114495C.description: Creativity and innovation. Students use innovative design processes to develop solutions to problems. Students plan a solution, create the solution, test the solution, iterate, and debug the solution as needed and implement a completely new and innovative product.

5E86F356800743C382D53378C685FB90.description: Computational thinking. Students break down the problem-solving process into four steps: decomposition, pattern recognition, abstraction, and algorithms.

1AF9C921B56948D68D2D76B24001AA30.description: The technology applications Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS) consist of five strands that prepare students to be literate in technology applications by Grade 8: computational thinking; creativity and innovation; data literacy, management, and representation; digital citizenship; and practical technology concepts. Communication and collaboration skills are embedded across the strands.

85DE85C492E44F58A61EEECF95B108BA.description: Technology includes data communication, data processing, and the devices used for these tasks locally and across networks. Learning to apply these technologies motivates students to develop critical-thinking skills, higher-order thinking, and innovative problem solving. Technology applications incorporates the study of digital tools, devices, communication, and programming to empower students to apply current and emerging technologies in their careers, their education, and beyond.

F705F8140E5A40A7B126F46A7AAF4F7D.description: If the commissioner does not make the determination that instructional materials funding has been made available under this subsection, the commissioner shall determine no later than August 1 of each subsequent school year whether instructional materials funding has been made available. If the commissioner determines that instructional materials funding has been made available, the commissioner shall notify the State Board of Education and school districts that this section shall be implemented for the following school year.

6707118FE0F94E3DA610D73310460242.description: If the commissioner makes the determination that instructional materials funding has been made available this section shall be implemented beginning with the 2024-2025 school year and apply to the 2024-2025 and subsequent school years.

908256486F674B9F8D0E4FCE8D16DF80.description: No later than August 1, 2024, the commissioner of education shall determine whether instructional materials funding has been made available to Texas public schools for materials that cover the essential knowledge and skills identified in this section.

7B395D31058E49BC9172F60173EFC9B1.description: Implementation. The provisions of this section shall be implemented by school districts beginning with the 2024-2025 school year.
